@Fish | lium.io  So not necessarily - the problem is currently you can only attach a function that is typed to return a Synapse object to an axon. For streaming, you're returning `BTStreamingResponse` though. 

And the reason why that works is because it never actually checks that a synapse is returned, so you can kinda 'sneak through' the `BTStreamingResponse` object. But obviously that shouldn't really happen - either you properly support it as an allowed return (and allow us to type them correctly) or you only accept Synapses as responses and allow for a way to attach the stream to the synapse. But right now it's just in the weird middle ground where everyone's using a 'loophole' to be able to stream

so basically the functions now look like:

```
def forward(...) -> ClassInheritingFromSynapse:
   ...
   return BTStreamingResponse(...)
```

whereas it should either be

```
def forward(...) -> BTStreamingResponse: # currently not allowed due to type checking for synapse return
   ...
   return BTStreamingResponse(...)
```
or

```
def forward(...) -> ClassInheritingFromSynapse:
   ...
   return ClassInheritingFromSynapse(...) # contains stream
```

**REMINDER: Potentially Breaking Update Coming**

This is a reminder for everyone that Tuesday an update that may potentially introduce breaking changes for validators is coming. Key parts of the update are:
- Full refactor of codebase (120 modified files, 7.5k deleted lines, 5k new lines of code)
- Added multiple choice task - this will allow us to understand the reasoning capabilities of SN1 better
- Added benchmarking: Currently the benchmarking results are still being reviewed internally, but once we have collected sufficient data and prepared a report we will publish in the coming week(s). This will make SN1 measurable compared to other SOTA models
- Lower value tasks (e.g. sentiment analysis) have been removed and will be replaced with new & better tasks in a second update coming out in 11 days!


**Please read the _original_ announcement to prepare for the update** (see the message that this one is responding to).

For questions please DM either @Hollyqui | Macrocosmos , @Ellesmier [τ, α] | Macrocosmos or @qriosiτy | Macrocosmos
what is alpha desgin for ?
can someone explain me  what is alpha like i am 5?
why you guys wanna move away from opentensor?

Could we keep the scoring for translation, sentiment, and math tasks, but just lower their weights? They add valuable diversity to the competition and stand out as the most distinctive advantages among these subnets

Macrocosmos is more or less a spin-off of OTF (our CTO is the ex-OTF CTO for instance). As a spin-off, we originally shared a good amount of resources with OTF, but with the idea to develop into a fully independent company over time. This means we have been migrating infrastructure away from being shared with OTF and are by now fully on our own infrastructure-wise. 

We still of course collaborate with them closely on advancing bittensor overall!

As a miner, you get some tasks (e.g. Question Answering based on wikipedia) and do you best to respond to them as well as possible. Validators score you on how well you're doing. In the end, we hope to have a subnetwork that has multiple different 'specialised agents', that are beyond state of the art in their respective area (e.g. web information retrieval, in the near future programming, multiple-choice question answering based on web content etc.)

We will be adding back new tasks - concretely adding multiple choice tomorrow (with the removal of translation, sentiment etc.) and then also general web retrieval + programming a week later.

The reason why we don't just want to set their weights to zero is that we refactored the whole codebase and would otherwise have to re-implement those tasks, and we'd prefere to focus our energy on more valuable tasks. In a way, implementing sentiment again isn't much less work than implementing a programming task, but the latter gives us much more value

To also explain the design decisions (for which tasks we choose): There's a problem at the moment in SN1 where there is not much of a power imbalance between miners and validators. For instance with translation, the validator has no inherent advantage over miners. 

With programming that's a little different, because we can use actual human written code, obfuscate/modify it on the validator and then get the miner to complete some of it. That way, the validator has the advantage of knowing what the human has written, whereas the miner does not.

Similarly for web retrieval, as a validator we can simply check how similar web results that the miner find are to our query, but the miner has to figure out a way how to quickly & efficiently conduct the search.

This has been a major limitation in making SN1 achieve results that are really beyond the SOTA. With translation we're capped by whatever we design on the validator, so that means we (Macrocosmos) would have to push the SOTA for every single task we develop which goes against the idea of a decentralised system that continues to improve:)

Hope that makes sense/explains why we don't really see much value in reimplementing the old tasks.


Also as a note: Math will return in a changed format, right now the issue is that we just have a very limited number of possible questions, which don't really train a good math model. We are considering different options how we can improve that though:)

I understand the effort involved in re-implementing tasks, but maintaining translation, sentiment, and math tasks would bridge the old and new tasks effectively. Given your team's technical prowess, integrating these tasks with the current codebase should be manageable. This not only preserves diversity in the tasks but also avoids over-concentration on a few types of tasks, potentially reducing the overall development and testing costs compared to entirely new tasks.

Additionally, complex models designed to handle advanced problems should also competently address simpler ones, much like an exam that includes fundamental questions. Retaining tasks like translation, sentiment, and math ensures that these models are evaluated for basic accuracy and robustness, preventing obvious mistakes on simpler problems. This reflects a well-rounded assessment of the models’ capabilities.

I'm not against the idea of adding some of them back in principle. But to give an example, right now translation simply uses a fixed number of prompts (literally a list of options) and then a translation package to do the translation. To get a perfect translation miner you can pretty much write the following (gotta use regex instead of .startswith to ignore the 'another language' part, but that's about it):


```
prompt_options = [
        "Could you assist me with translating the following text into {another_language}?",
        "I need some help translating this text into {another_language}. Can you do it?",
        ...
        "Hey, could you take a moment to translate this text into {another_language} for me?",
    ]
# challenge is the query provided form the validator
for prompt in prompt_options:
   if challenge.startswith(prompt):
       return argostranslate.translate.translate('\n'.join(challenge.split('\n')[1:]))

# check for/handle other task types here
```

@Hollyqui | Macrocosmos  I agree with the above and provide another perspective: frequently adding new tasks is inherently unfriendly to developers. Removing a large number of existing tasks would undoubtedly lower the costs and efforts for developers in creating new tasks, but this uncertainty also reduces our incentive as developers to continue developing models since no one knows when these tasks might be removed again. I think the officials should be more cautious in considering any task changes, especially decisions about removing any tasks.

By the way - over the last months we had a lot of technical work with the refactor (which was a huge PR), and we're already working towards some other pretty big PRs (e.g. https://github.com/macrocosm-os/prompting/pull/344 - which allows us to use multiple different LLMs for reference generation + adds a task of simply 'generate using X open source model' which will later be used for ensembling responses effectively).

I plan on publishing a proper roadmap soon, just waiting for our comms guys to help with writing it up nicely since writing is most certainly not my strength! I think once that's out, it'll also help to explain a lot of the decisions we're making right now - I can totally appreciate they currently seem a little strange. The truth is that SN1 needs change and we've not yet communicated the longer-term roadmap!:)

That's a completely fair point - like always this has two sides though: Right now we've got a few miners running _multiple hundreds_ of UIDs. I can also argue that having some level of task rotation/slimming down levels the playing field a little and incentivises more new miners to join. 

Also to be clear: we aren't planning to do this regularly and this is a one-off thing due to massive tech debt that the refactor is getting rid of!

I appreciate the input from everyone by the way - it's very helpful to get some insights from the miner side! Unfortunately for this one we can't change the decision since the refactor will have to go out tomorrow, but we have no plans/intention of removing a number of tasks again in the near future and if we do I promise that it will be considered carefully.

Thank you for your thoughtful response. Could you clarify how it was determined that only a few miners are running multiple hundreds of UIDs? Additionally, could you explain why this behavior is viewed as problematic and necessitates adjustment?
Based on the publicly available information on taostats, I haven't noticed any miners with more than a few dozen UIDs.

Ha that's a good question! When we query all miners with the same query, we can simply check which number of them give identical responses and have a pretty safe guess they're the same UID. additionally, we can check which coldkeys their hotkeys are associated with (often many hotkeys will reference the same coldkeys) and then IP addresses. 

The first one (checking answers) is the most reliable though. To note though, I have not done this work myself and maybe people are running fewer UIDs nowadays, it's possible this stat is dated. Probably @Ellesmier [τ, α] | Macrocosmos can contribute info on when exactly we looked at this.

---

Regarding why it needs adjustment: Imagine I have a miner that works well and am one of the top few guys. Due to the fairly flat reward distribution (to be changed) of SN1, I make more profit on 2 UIDs than on one. The more UIDs I own, the better for me. So there's an inherent benefit for me to buy up as many as I can.

Now say the top 10 miners jointly own 1k UIDs (that's probably not the case, just an illustrative example). That means the profits get (more or less) split into 1/10th each. Each of those miners can run the hardware quite cheaply, because for most queries they only compute one single response and then relay that through all their UIDs.

Now if I now want to join as a new miner and I have a system that's equally as good and I buy up a UID, I have to run that same hardware, but I only get 1/100th of the reward, so probably I will be losing money and therefore have no incentive to compete unless I can buy a large number of UIDs. If I wanted to compete with the other top miners and buy 100UIDs that would also cost ~10k USD which I would have to put in as upfront investment + server architecture to scale compute efficiently between them.

Another problem is that in the future we will want to ensemble different miner responses together which requires some level of response diversity. If I query 10 miners and only get 2 distinct responses I can't do much with that.

Part of the roadmap will be to make the reward distribution a lot less flat and allow miners to specialise in tasks. That means you as a new miner can pick one task you'd like to specialise in, only get good that that and then still capture a pretty good amount of reward. That drops the need to be good at everything/maintaining every single task. 

This won't quite be winner-takes-all per task, but going into that direction. That way running multiple UIDs is less appealing (it doesn't give you much of a benefit) which in turn will lower registration costs, make SN1 more accessible and also lessen the burden of miners to keep up with new tasks as you will likely try and find one or a few to specialise in where you will be the best miner, but ignore the bulk of other tasks!

Honestly really excited for this - currently part of this UID battle, it takes away from improving the model to improving the buy-in strategy. 

This change will be very much welcomed by the entire community, in my opinion. 

Keep up the good work!

Hey @~ a.choji | GTV I literally wrote the release notes 10 minutes ago, waiting for @qriosiτy | Macrocosmos and @Ellesmier [τ, α] | Macrocosmos to review before sending them out;)

To give you a very rough idea:
Programming Task, Web retrieval task coming on Tuesday
Inference Task coming on Tuesday in a very mellowed-out format where it is equivalent to today's organic scoring, but with a few changes in a config file we can enforce that specific LLMs are run on the miner side. 

Changes to the reward function (hopefully) coming out the Tuesday after, with risk of delay by one week.

**Version 2.8.0 Release**
We are excited to announce another huge release (2k+ new lines of code) for SN1! Next Tuesday (around 3pm UK time) we will be launching
- A new programming task
- A new web retrieval task
- An inference task (which is initially identical to organic scoring, but will allow us to at any time in the future allow us to specify exact LLMs for miners to run)
- A new synapse (AvailabilitySynapse)
- A modification to the synapses: We are now providing you the information what type of task is being sent over. We know you guys have a classifier head working on it anyways, so we figured we might as well save you some work maintaining it.

**For validators**
There are no breaking changes. Please ensure updating in a timely manner to ensure that you stay in consensus with the introduction of new tasks. You may see warnings about missing synapses at increased frequencies as miners are adjusting to changes in the synapse structure.

**For Miners**
We have introduced a few new tasks, as well as a new synapse.

Programming Task:
We retrieve a random code snippet from github. This code snippet will then be augmented using llama 70B (variables renamed, comments reworded, functions renamed etc.) and cut off at a random point. It will then be your task to complete the next 5 lines after the cutoff.

Web Retrieval:
You will effectively be conducting RAG across the whole internet. We will provide you with a random question for which you need to find a website that contains a paragraph of a minimum length which is most similar to the original query.
In the future, we will introduce incentives to respond quickly, as well as reward diversity of retrieved websites.
Inference:
The inference task is initially identical to the organic scoring task (which it replaces). We have the code structure in place to require you to respond with an exact model (e.g. llama 8B or so). This will be used to:
- allow us to benchmark SN1 against popular open source models
- load models from SN9 & SN37 onto SN1 and make them available in Chattensor
- conduct research into ensembling models
- allow us to combine the inference task with e.g. the web retrieval task to generate high-quality answers on content across the internet

**Availability Synapse**
Using the availability synapse, you can communicate to validators which tasks you respond to as well as which LLMs you are providing. By default, we assume that you respond to all tasks, but have no LLMs loaded (this is also the case if you do not yet have the availability synapse implemented). We **strongly** recommend implementing the Synapse asap as in future iterations of the reward function you may be penalised strongly if you do not respond to a task that you claim to be handling via your AvailabilitySynapse.

**Future Releases**

In the near future, we will release a significant change to the reward function. In the new iteration of the reward function, all tasks (except for inference) will move towards a task-wise winner-takes-all model. This means, you will want to use your AvailabilitySynapse to indicate which tasks you'd like to compete on, and will be sent exclusively requests for those tasks.
The inference task will follow a proportional reward function (based on throughput) - so if you respond to twice as many requests as someone else, you will be getting twice the reward. The overall reward pool will be split between all other tasks and inference. Concretely, this means (with random numbers, as we're still working out correct ratios):
Inference: Shares 30% of all rewards between all miners responding to inference task proportionally to the number of requests handled
Other Tasks:
- Programming: 10% - the person who performs best on the programming task will get 10% of all the reward on the network
- Web retrieval: 10% - the person who performs best on the programming task will get 10% of all the reward on the network
- Wikipedia QA: 15% - ...
...

Since all the information is public, starting with your own research might be the most efficient approach. Should you have any questions or need clarifications afterward, I’m sure the community would be happy to discuss them!

Very insightful! Distinguishing between innovation and throughput is a revolutionary idea! Perhaps in the future, we could consider carefully allocating the reward weights between the two aspects, like a 40:60 split, to separately incentivize each area. This might further optimize our approach as the network evolves.

Yeah, that's exactly the idea! The inference task is responsible for throughput, so the % share of reward of inference is exactly equivalent to what you're describing. Initially we'll start quite low (focus on innovation) and then as we pick up users move to exploitation/throughput.

Perhaps starting closer to the existing model could provide a more reasonable transition. Initially, a 40:60 or 50:50 split between innovation and throughput could balance the rewards, ensuring that both areas are incentivized without making the majority of the ~1000 miners feel undervalued. This balance could help maintain engagement while the network scales.

And this is obviously still a little while away and we may revise our plans until then, but the hope is also that we might be able to incentivise 'innovation miners' to share their models in exchange for some royalty-based rewards that they get when people are requesting their models in the inference task. Again, there's still a lot of questions to work out to make this work, but it's ideas we're entertaining

That's a good point. I think initially we probably have to start low on the inference task to maintain vtrust unfortunately but tbf it's a very good point, so we may want to consider raising the raito very quickly towards the 40:60 you're proposing

I appreciate the forward-thinking approach and the idea of incentivizing 'innovation miners' with royalty-based rewards. It's a promising concept that could enrich the ecosystem. I fully support exploring these ideas, as long as we ensure a reasonable transition period and keep focusing on what's best for this SN. All rules that benefit the network are worth discussing and perfecting.

Yeah - we will probably have somewhat of a consolidation period coming up now as well - we had two month of pretty intense updates now starting with the refactor and with the introduction of new tasks we'll try and focus on some changes that don't affect miners so much to let everyone get used to the new reward landscape/see what models you guys develop:)

So we'll probably spend a sprint or two on fixing our currently slightly broken unit tests, (hopefully) updating to use liquid alpha to prevent weight copying, publishing some benchmarking results etc. Once we feel like everything is back to being stable and we find that the new reward landscape yields good results we'll have our next push of changes.

**For Miners:**

This would make a good addition to the readme. Currently the tasks are as follows:

QA: Miner receives a question about a specific section from a wikipedia page. The miner must then find the original context, and use it to return an answer.

Summarization: Same as QA but using the whole wikipedia page instead of a section.

DateQA: Miner receives a question about an event from wikipedia, then the miner must search wikipedia for the answer and return it.

Inference: Seeded inference. 

MultiChoice: A question is generated from Wikipedia with 4 possible answers. The miner must find the answer on wikipedia and return an A, B, C, or D corresponding to the correct answer.

Programming: Complete the code snippet.

Web Retrieval: Given a question, the miner must return a scraped website to answer the question.

**2.9.0 Release Announcement**

We are introducing a new version of the web retrieval task as well as a new reward landscape! Our new retrieval task will make miners return their sources to allow us to understand where content is coming from. The new reward landscape introduces a parameter p which will adjust how flat the landscape is. At p=0 every miner will get the same reward regardless of performance, at p=0.5 the reward will be unchanged (compared to now) and at p=1 the reward will be (nearly) winner-takes-all.

**For Validators**
Please ensure you update to the newest version. The reward landscape has changed, so you will fall out of consensus if you do not update.

**For Miners:**

Web retrieval:
- The web retrieval task has changed, now requiring structured output + sources. Please make sure you return the correct format.

Reward Landscape:

The reward landscape has been modified so each task has a constant share of all rewards. This share will be split across all miners participating in that task. The steepness on a per-task basis will be relative to parameter p as explained above.
We are starting p at 0.5 (almost no change) but will slowly move it up towards 1, meaning the best miner gets the full reward share for each task, reducing any incentive to game the system with owning a large number of uids.

That means it is now becoming increasingly important to be the best at one task, whereas good performance over a variety of tasks will not be rewarded as strongly. In the near-term future we will also introduce terms to give negative reward for failing to respond/responding with nonsense values, so please make sure that you integrate the AvailabilitySynapse to allow us to only query your miner for tasks you actually perform on. This is especially relevant for the Inference task where we will strongly discourage lack of responses.

If you find/notice any issues, please message @Ellesmier [τ, α] | Macrocosmos , @qriosiτy | Macrocosmos or myself ( @Hollyqui | Macrocosmos )

So we're very much open to ideas - the problem we face is that if one person performs very well they are incentivised to buy up as many uids to capture as many rewards as possible. In the long run that means that registration costs go up and only a very small number of people can be competitive. So in order to keep the subnetwork competitive, we have to try eliminating the fact that one person is incentivised to buy up a very large number of uids

If there's a non-winner takes all reward function that doesn't lead to the best miner buying up the majority of UIDS we'd be all for it, but so far we couldn't find anything. 

But we really welcome ideas/input

By ensuring that top performers earn significantly more than those ranked lower (e.g., 2 to 3 times more), they can more easily balance rewards and costs. The top performers receive real rewards, while others get "consolation prizes." This way, top performers have less incentive to acquire a large number of UIDs.
I checked it. it was due to some python module dependency errors. Problems solved! thx for ur time

Yeah - we might consider consolation prices as long as they are not profitable (effectively miners can try out things at a very low cost) - otherwise if you give e.g. the top 3 miners decent rewards you just end up with one guy buying 3 uids again unfortunately. But let's see - we'll slowly increase p and see how it affects the network

My idea is that if, as you said, only the top 3, top 30, or even top 300 UIDs receive reasonable rewards, that is acceptable because it won't lead to the majority of registrations being controlled by one person (e.g., OTF) and still provides appropriate opportunities for newcomers. I believe all AI researchers agree that the C/P ratio of running models is one of many trade-offs. Perhaps the best models require enormous hardware resources (e.g., NVIDIA H200), so only being in the top 2 yields benefits. Smaller models have lower costs, making being in the top 50 beneficial, even if they can't beat the top. This natural balance can reward throughput across various tasks, so having a distribution curve rather than an extreme setting is actually more reasonable.

That's an interesting point that I tbf didn't consider yet. The scaling of forcing a distribution of stronger + weaker models depending on rank based on emission curve is an interesting one, that's actually a really good point. Let me discuss with the team:)

Hey @Monk Kukai 
For the web retrieval task, miners are supposed to return a JSON string with the fields: 
`url`, `content`, `relevant` fields, where
`url` is the website URL from which the content was scraped,
`content` is the full extracted content of the website,
`relevant` is a relevant chunk of text that answers the prompt.

For example:
```
{
    "url": "https://www.example.com",
    "content": "This is the content of the website. This is the section we are interested in.",
    "relevant": "This is the section we are interested in.",
}
```
https://github.com/macrocosm-os/prompting/blob/main/prompting/rewards/web_retrieval.py#L1


The multi-choice task preferably expects also a JSON string with probabilities assigned to each letter. For example:
```{"A": 0.1, "B": 0.3, "C": 0.6, "D": 0.0}```
Although it supports the previous approach for backward compatibility, where a miner can return just a single letter `A`, `B`, `C` or `D`, but the reward will be 10% less compared to the JSON logits response.

Sorry I don't fully understand what you mean here. 

The idea of web retrieval is that we generate a random question and you find whatever website most closely answers that questions. You don't have to find the same website that we used - just whichever one is closest in embedding space.

You also don't have to use dgg, you can use Google or Bing or write your own search engine.

The idea for web retrieval is that it can eventually be used to combine with the inference task to allow us to very efficiently search the web for content to a user's question and generate answers, so whether you get the exact same website doesn't matter
Note that setting up a new Subnet costs about 2.000.000$ at current registration prices, so unless you are particularly wealthy or have raised VC funding probably not possible

**2.10.0  Release Announcement**

TLRD: 
- New dataset from SN13 for inference task
- Increased steepness of reward landscape (p=0.6)
- Improved Multiple Choice

We are excited to announce that after our collaboration with SN37 we are now also collaborating with SN13 by using their dataset for our inference task! This should neither affect miners not validators as miners will still be best off simply running llama 70B without modifications for the inference task.
Additionally, we will increase the steepness of the reward landscape slightly by increasing


**Heads up for 2.11.0 and 2.12.0**

Release 2.11.0 will come out next tuesday and contain a **BREAKING CHANGE FOR VALIDATORS**. We are connecting SN1 with SN19 for the generation of queries. In the new version, SN19's 1500tokens/second are going to help us increase the rate of generation of tasks. All generation of references will still be locally on the SN1 validator, meaning nothing will change about the eval function. As a fallback we have decided to also allow validators to add an OpenAI API key in case there are any stability issues on SN19. 

As a validator you:
- MUST add an openai key (should not be billed and is purely a fallback)
- SHOULD add your SN19 server credentials (free for validators)

# Release 2.11.0 Pre-Announcement 
We are connecting SN1 with SN19 for the generation of queries. In the new version, SN19's 1500tokens/second throughput are going to help us increase the rate of generation of tasks. All generation of references will still be locally on the SN1 validator, meaning nothing will change about the eval function. As a fallback we have decided to also allow validators to add an OpenAI API key in case there are any stability issues on SN19.

**For Validators:**
you:
- **MUST** add an openai key (should not be billed and is purely a fallback)

- **SHOULD** add your SN19 server credentials (free for validators) to avoid having to pay for OpenAI services

**For Miners**
No changes required
---
Note that us using GPT as a fallback to not reflect a change in direction to move away from our commitment to open-source software, but all validators already have an account (due to validation work on SN18), which makes it a convenient fallback. Under normal circumstances, all query generation will be happening through our SN19 connection using open source models; all reference generation will happen locally on the validator.

In case of questions/feedback reach out to @Ellesmier [τ, α] | Macrocosmos,  @qriosiτy | Macrocosmos or @Hollyqui | Macrocosmos
still no frontend?

We're currently in the process of building a single frontend across all Macrocosmos subnets (subnet 1, 9, 13, 25, and 37). This is why we do not have a front-end for subnet 1 yet, as it will be part of our larger, interconnected goals. Because of this, we have spent our time up until this point making sure the subnet produces the best results possible before building our macrocosmos-wide interface.

Alongside this, we will be launching a suite of products with front-ends that will allow miners to bring more value across all subnet 1 tasks. This is happening within the quarter.

I would note SN1's results are available in several front ends (TaoBot, Corcel, etc), and our focus as an organisation is primarily on creating world class commodities before overfitting to front-ends (which many subnets have tried and then deprecated). We have produced a basic chat interface that we are running and will probably open source, but at the moment we don't see it as a competitive product with closed source providers, and are building something a little more comprehensive that integrates many pieces of Bittensor

**Important Information For Validators:**

We have noticed that a lot of validators aren't sure where to get the SN19 server credentials from - in case you're also not sure how to get them I hope the instructions below help. We'll also be adding them to our README.md. If you still have any questions please just reach out to me ( @Hollyqui | Macrocosmos )

---

If you're already validating on SN19 you might already have a server setup for SN19 - if you don't you can follow the instructions here: https://github.com/namoray/vision/blob/production/docs/validating.md#managing-organic-access

Once you have this server set up, you simply paste the link to that server (e.g.  http://24.199.109.169:8091) and the API Key (generated by yourself in the instructions above) into the .env.validator file on SN1.

If you aren't validating on SN19 you can also just use an OpenAI API key without SN19, but then you will incur some extra costs from OpenAI.

This is what the relevant part of the env file should look like:

...
OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-proj-LjxqoFGDra_zqlEHC...........................0a4R_D1PuB22w04EuGL2loA"
SN19_API_KEY="f56.....4c23"
SN19_API_URL="http://24.199.109.169:8091/"
...

The openai key is mandatory to serve as a fallback if there are problems with SN19 whereas the SN19 ones are optional, but providing them means you won't have any extra costs for OpenAI

Hey SN1 Miners! We have a large release planned for next Tuesday. Along with some fixes for stability and consistency, we will be releasing a **Breaking Change** to inference. We are moving to seeded inference, which means that you will be scored with a binary tag on whether you have exactly matched the expected output of the validator. This means that your miner should use an identical system prompt, user prompt, and seed. We will be using the transformers library to ensure seeding works accross machines. Please have a look at the `release/v2.12.0` branch to get a head start on the change that will be coming next week. This will allow us to cycle between different models, which will bring fine-grained control over miners through our API, which is coming soon. If you are unable to run the `"hugging-quants/Meta-Llama-3.1-70B-Instruct-AWQ-INT4"` model, I'd recommend adjusting your availability synapse to reflect this. As weights are set on a `per-task` basis, the effect that this will have on your scores should be minimal, though obviously if a miner is able to run this model, they will have an advantage.

Hey guys. The results we/I announced were based on R&D on ensembling techniques, where multiple responses are combined during inference time into a single enhanced response. Our findings support what together.ai claimed about the improved performance of ensembling versus individual LLM outputs. 

We analyzed the performance of individual miner responses on benchmarks and then combined them in various ways with additional inference (ensembling) steps. The results are from R&D efforts using SN1 historical data, but we've begun incorporating the technique into SN1's code as a composite task (consisting of multiple forward steps) so that everyone can start playing with the new feature.

messages.content:
Hey Subnet 1, because of the impending chain update that will require us to update to the latest version of Bittensor, we have to change the way that we handle streaming. Because of this, we will be adopting the epistula protocol developed by @josh | Manifold Labs [τ, ∆]  at Manifold Labs, and using the streaming endpoints that sn4 uses as well. This will be a large change to the networking of SN1. The "synapses" will be replaced by post calls using the openai library. For your miner, this will appear as a request object with messages (in the openai format [{'role': 'user', 'content': 'abcde....'}]) and a model (if the task specifies it, otherwise it will be None). The seed, task name, and other information can be found in the headers of the request, along with verification information. I've provided two ways that you can stream back your response through the openai endpoint, one will allow you to forward an llms output coming from another openai endpoint (vllm, openai, etc..) as a stream, the other is more basic and will pseudo-stream back a string in chunks. The availability synapse will also be another fastapi server that a miner offers, tho calls for availability are much simpler, and do not use the openai endpoint and do not stream. Please have a look soon and start implementing ASAP. We are planning on shipping this next Teusday, or when OTF ships their chain update, whichever comes first. In the interest of giving y'all the most amount of time possible, I've published the branch. It is still a work in progress, but the fundamental changes to epistula are completed, and a working miner file is provided in `prompting/neurons/miners/epistula_miner/miner.py`. Please reply to this message with any questions that you may have, or any errors that you encounter. You may also be forced to update your bittensor version because of the update, so please check.

Checkout the branch here: https://github.com/macrocosm-os/prompting/tree/SN1-260-rework-validator-to-use-epistula

Hey Subnet1,
This is another release reminder, with a little more details about the **Breaking Change** coming to SN1 on Tuesday. Miners are going to be heavily affected. 

**Communication Protocol**
We will be switching from synapses and dendrite calls to the Epistula Protocol and Openai Chat Endpoints. Another huge shoutout to Josh and the rest of Manifold Labs for the direction and assistance in this switch. Validators will be updated as they pull the newest version, but miners will have to manually make the switch. We've provided a working example of a miner that uses the Epistula protocol in the repo with the new streaming endpoints.

**Deterministic Inference** 
We will be sending sampling parameters, the seed, and messages that we used to generate the reference in the body of the payload. The intent is that miners will reproduce exact matches to the reference for inference tasks that have a model specified. Otherwise an exact match is not necessary. 

**Bittensor Update** 
The core reason for these updates is the chain update that will require subnets to update to the most recent 8.x.x bittensor package. We have chosen the most recent release 8.3.1. This will require validators to run the install script to rebuild the environment after they pull they most recent changes. Miners will also likely have to update to interact with chain. 

**Transition to VLLM**
Due to the bittensor update requiring numpy > 2.0.0, as well as our move to deterministic inference, we will be using the transformers library to generate references.

If you have any questions about implementation, or any errors that you notice in the codebase, please don't hesitate to reach out. Though the codebase is still being cleaned up, most of the changes have been completed. 

Checkout the branch here: https://github.com/macrocosm-os/prompting/tree/SN1-260-rework-validator-to-use-epistula

messages.content: Bullish for sn1
No not another deterministic subnet

@Fish | lium.io No need to worry - we will not become a deterministic inference subnet. 

Deterministic inference is important for us for two reasons:
- be able to compare our miners performance to various open source models (deterministic inference is needed to get the comparison to open source and hopefully show that our miners actually outperform it)
- use it as a layer between chat tensor and the task-specific models miners are creating to make it more user friendly. This means we're applying the deterministic inference to process & ensemble the responses given by miners using their proprietary models
It also only makes up 2.2% of network traffic

1. How can you outperform open source if it’s deterministic?
2. What’s the reason of ensembling deterministic responses if they are the same?

I guess the owner might come up with creative ideas in the future, like introducing deterministic inference that doesn’t lock everyone into the exact same seed (with temperature > 0). Even with deterministic setups, having diverse, quickly accessible responses can still be super valuable

We have 7 different 'tasks/challenges' on sn1, _one_ of which is deterministic inference. So we're hoping that miners on the other tasks (programming, reasoning etc.) outperform the models run on deterministic inference. 

In the ensembling we take the other tasks (e.g. 5 miners with different proprietary programming models) that get ensembles and parsed into a comprehensive response using deterministic inference
So we may for instance use llama 405B, give it 5 different answers produced by our miner's coding models and then produce one ensembled answer that is displayed to users in the chat interface

A note is we are also looking in detail at using combinations of extended inference time and combining multiple models and responses to improve overall subnet performance. We’ll be sharing more on this in due course. our focus is still and continues to be on driving asymmetric intelligence over purely seeded deterministic inference, and we’re focusing on evolutions in incentive design in this space.
